case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, New Delhi v. the respondent Company

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 559 of 1960 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 559 of 1960. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal against Income-tax Appellate Tribunal order dated May 1/14, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated May 1/14, 1957, of the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal of India  Delhi Bench  in T.A. No. 2070 of 1956-57.

facts.text: Tribunal reversed Appellate Assistant Commissioner and held loss from sale of shares was not a capital loss.

anchor.surface_text: reversing the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, held that a loss arising from the sale of certain shares by the respondent Company was a capital loss.

facts.text: Notice of Tribunal order received by Commissioner on July 15, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The notice of the order was sent to the Commissioner of Income-tax, New Delhi, and reached his office by registered post on July 15, 1957.

facts.text: Clerk Motilal Pathak fell ill on July 15, 1957, and date stamp affixed on July 16, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: It was received by one Motilal Pathak, a clerk in the office of the Commissioner. Motilals affidavit shows that, he suddenly fell ill, and had to take casual leave for the day.

facts.text: Application for reference to High Court dismissed by Tribunal as barred by one day on December 4, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Tribunal, therefore, dismissed the application on December 4, 1957.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave against Tribunal order due to special circumstances similar to Baldev Singh case.

anchor.surface_text: This Court then granted special leave against the order of the Tribunal passed in the appeal before it

facts.text: Assessee is National Finance Ltd., New Delhi, public limited company incorporated in 1943, deals in shares and securities and as financiers.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee Company is the National Finance Ltd., New Delhi. It is a public limited Company which was incorporated in 1943.

facts.text: Assessee sold 3,000 shares of Madhusudan Mills Ltd. suffering loss of Rs. 5,48,712-8-0 in year May 1, 1949 to April 30, 1950 (assessment year 1951-52).

anchor.surface_text: In the year of account, May 1, 1949, to April 30, 1950, corresponding to the assessment year, 1951-52, the assessee Company sold these shares suffering a loss

facts.text: Loss claimed as on sale of stock-in-trade by assessee; ITO and AAC held capital loss; Tribunal held trading loss.

anchor.surface_text: which it claimed as one on the sale of its stock-in- trade. The Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner held it to be a capital loss.

facts.text: Companies controlled by Yodh Raj Bhalla group: Jaswant Sugar Mills Ltd., Jaswant Straw Boards Ltd., National Finance Ltd., etc.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee Company belongs to a group of Companies controlled by one Lala Yodh Raj Bhalla and certain persons associated with him.

facts.text: In July 1948, Yodh Raj Bhalla arranged purchase of 26,547 shares of Madhusudan Mills (80% of capital) from Bhadani Brothers at Rs. 400/share (market Rs. 250).

anchor.surface_text: In July 1948, Mr. Yodh Raj Bhalla... arranged to purchase 26,547 shares of the Mills from Messrs. Bhadani Brothers, Ltd... at Rs. 400 per share, when the price

facts.text: Purchase funded by: assessee Rs. 14,75,000; National Construction Rs. 5,00,000; assessee via Ganesh Rs. 55,00,000.

anchor.surface_text: The arrangement for the money was as follows Rs. 14,75,000- borrowed from the assesee Company. Rs. 5,00,000- from National Construction

facts.text: 10,500 shares registered in name of assessee; 5,400 in National Construction; balance in nominees of Jaswant Sugar Mills.

anchor.surface_text: The shares were registered as follows 10,500 shares registered in the name of the assessee Company.

facts.text: On October 9, 1949, assessee purchased 15,547 shares from Jaswant Sugar Mills at Rs. 400/share (market Rs. 217-8-0).

anchor.surface_text: On October 9, 1949, the assessee Company purchased 15,547 shares at Rs. 400 per share from Jaswant Sugar Mills Ltd.

facts.text: Assessee appointed purchasing and selling agent of Madhusudan Mills on date of purchase from Bhadani.

anchor.surface_text: on the same day on which the shares were purchased from these managing agents, the assessee Company was appointed as the purchasing and selling agent

facts.text: On June 1, 1949, assessee sold 3,000 shares to Amrit Bhushan at Rs. 180/share, loss Rs. 5,86,312.

anchor.surface_text: on June 1, 1949, another block of 3,000 shares was sold to the National Investment Trust Ltd., at Rs. 180 per share, resulting in a loss

facts.text: Amrit Bhushan, relative of Yodh Raj Bhalla, sold the 3,000 shares same day to National Investment Trust at profit of 8 annas/share (brokerage).

anchor.surface_text: The shares which were sold by the assessee Company on the two occasioning were sold to one Amrit Bhushan  a relative of Mr. Yodh Raj Bhalla  who sold then

facts.text: ITO disallowed loss as capital loss for 1951-52, confirmed by AAC, reversed by Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment year, 1951-52, the loss of Rs. 5,86,312-8-0 on the sale of 3,000 shares was, therefore, disallowed holding it to be a capital loss.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds loss is capital loss, not trading loss.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this transaction must be regarded as one on the capital side.

facts.text: Shares purchased at almost double market price to acquire control and agency, not for trading.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt, whatever, that the shares of the Madhusudan Mills Ltd. were acquired at a price considerably higher than the market price.

facts.text: Group companies practically own each other through shareholdings over 80-96%.

anchor.surface_text: Jaswant Sugar Mills Ltd. 2,00,000 shares Jaswant Straw Board Ltd. 44,845 National Finance Ltd. 67,390 ... i.e. over 80 per cent

facts.text: Preliminary objection by respondent on competence of appeal overruled by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, overrule the preliminary objection.

facts.text: On April 7, 1949, assessee sold 4,500 shares at Rs. 181/share, loss Rs. 8,80,000 (for 1950-51).

anchor.surface_text: On April 7, 1949, 4,500 shares were sold by the assessee Company to the National Investment Trust Ltd. at Rs. 181 per share resulting in a loss

facts.text: In Oct/Nov 1948, 6,525 shares sold to Dalmia Cement at Rs. 400/share.

anchor.surface_text: In October and November, 1948 they, however, sold 6,525 shares to Dalmia Cement and Marketing Company Ltd. at Rs. 400 per share.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 1/14, 1957, of the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal of India  Delhi Bench  in T.A. No. 2070 of 1956-57.

concepts.interpretation: Court entertains direct appeal from Tribunal order under special leave due to exceptional circumstances like clerical error in date stamping.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: decision of the Tribunal in the circumstances was incompetent. A similar view was again expressed in two other cases, viz., Indian Aluminium Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Against the decision of the Tribunal, an application was filed in the High Court under s. 66 3  of the Income-tax Act but the High Court dismissed the application,

issues.text: Whether the appeal is competent and should be heard directly from the order of the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal by special leave under Article 136, or the leave should be revoked, in view of the decision in Chandi Prasad Chokhani's case, given the special circumstances of clerical error in date stamping due to clerk's illness.

anchor.surface_text: This Court then granted special leave against the order of the Tribunal passed in the appeal before it, and the question is whether the appeal should be heard or the leave revoked, in view of the decision in Chokhanis case 1 .

issues.text: Whether the loss arising from the sale of 3,000 shares of Madhusudan Mills Ltd. by the assessee company is a trading loss allowable as business loss or a capital loss.

anchor.surface_text: The only question in this appeal is whether the decision of the Tribunal is right. The assessee Company belongs to a group of Companies companytrolled by one Lala Yodh Raj Bhalla

issues.text: Whether the question of whether a loss is trading or capital involves a mixed question of fact and law allowing appellate interference.

anchor.surface_text: that the question is not one of pure fact, and that a mixed question of fact and law is always involved. The cases to which we shall make a reference presently,

issues.text: Whether the intention of the Yodh Raj Bhalla group in acquiring the shares at above market price can be attributed to the assessee company despite separate legal entity principle.

holdings.text: The appeal is competent and the preliminary objection is overruled due to special circumstances analogous to Baldev Singh case.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, overrule the preliminary objection. The assessee Company is the National Finance Ltd., New Delhi. It is a public limited Company which was incorporated in 1943. It deals in shares and securities and also as financiers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clerical error in date stamping due to clerk's sudden illness on receipt date (July 15, 1957), no negligence by Commissioner, combination of circumstances led to one-day delay, justified direct appeal under Art. 136 like Baldev Singh.

holdings.text: Tribunal had no jurisdiction to extend limitation for reference application as it was barred by one day.

anchor.surface_text: It is evident that the decision of the Tribunal was quite correct, and the Tribunal had no option but to dismiss the application, since the law gives no jurisdiction to the Tribunal to extend limitation, as is done under s. 5 of the Indian Limitation Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal lacks power under Income-tax Act to condone delay unlike courts under Limitation Act s.5; application filed one day late based on erroneous date stamp.

holdings.text: Determining whether a loss is trading loss or capital loss involves a mixed question of fact and law, not pure fact.

anchor.surface_text: But it has been held, over and over again, that the question is not one of pure fact, and that a mixed question of fact and law is always involved. The cases to which we shall make a reference presently,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established by precedents; allows appellate interference; approach via intention of assessee at acquisition.

holdings.text: Loss arising from sale of 3,000 shares of Madhusudan Mills Ltd. is capital loss, not trading loss allowable as business loss.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this transaction must be regarded as one on the capital side. Shares were never treated as part of the stock-in-trade. They were not sold in the market, but were sold at a loss to another Company belonging to the same group,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intention at acquisition was to secure control (80% shares at double market price Rs.400 vs Rs.250) and profitable purchasing/selling agency (enduring benefit), not resale; applied 'adventure in nature of trade' test from Ramnarain Sons; shares not stock-in-trade.

holdings.text: Intention of Yodh Raj Bhalla group in acquiring shares for control and agency is attributable to assessee company despite separate legal entity principle.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Group companies under common control by same persons; interposition of Jaswant Sugar Mills as temporary holder was device; assessee immediately benefited from agency; Salomon principle inapplicable to pierce for true intention on capital vs trading.
